awd_titl_txt: Cognitive and motor factors in vocal imitation
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to imitate the actions of others plays a critical role in motor learning throughout life. In many cases, imitation can rely on visual observations of an expert's actions, as when a child learns to use a spoon. Imitation with the voice, used when learning to produce the sounds of an unfamiliar language or when learning to sing a song, poses a different problem because one cannot see many of the movements that are involved. Indeed, many people find vocal imitation difficult. However, because the mechanisms underlying this ability are poorly understood, instructors have few resources with which to help such individuals.  The research program focuses on vocal imitation of pitch, a feature that is central to both music and speech production. The hypothesis guiding these experiments is that formation of a mental image of the to-be-achieved goal mediates and stimulates neural associations between auditory and motor networks that allow the actual production to be accurate. By contrast, a less skilled speaker or singer will not have formed as strong auditory-motor associations.

Three studies will examine participants imitating pitch patterns associated with song or speech. Spoken pitch samples will be based on English, where pitch is mostly used to convey emphasis, and Mandarin, where pitch is associated with word meanings. Participants in this research will include singers and non-singers, as well as individuals who speak Mandarin and those who do not. Planned studies will 1) assess basic cognitive processes (mental imagery, working memory, and perception) that contribute to imitation accuracy; 2) use electromyography to address whether auditory mental images are associated with sub-vocal muscle movements; and 3) explore the role that specific learning experience has on individuals' capacity to imitate. Results from these studies will be used to improve instruction for learning to speak a tone language and for singing. More effective instructional techniques could enhance the capacity and experience of those learning to speak and sing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The ability to imitate the actions of others plays a critical role in motor learning throughout life. In many cases, imitation can rely on visual observations of an expert’s actions, as when a child learns to use a spoon. Imitation with the voice, used when learning to produce the sounds of an unfamiliar language or when learning to sing a song, poses a different problem, given that one cannot see many of the movements that are involved. Indeed, many people find vocal imitation difficult. However, because the mechanisms underlying this ability are poorly understood, instructors have few resources with which to help such individuals.  Research funded by NSF focuses on vocal imitation of pitch, a feature that is central to both music and speech production. The hypothesis guiding these experiments is that formation of a mental image of the to-be-achieved goal mediates and stimulates neural associations between auditory and motor networks that allow the actual production to be accurate. By contrast, a less skilled singer will not have formed as strong auditory-motor associations. NSF funding has facilitated several discoveries using this framework: Three key results are summarized here.

 

1: Prior experience influences imitation ability, in different ways

In one study, participants imitated pitch patterns extracted from English or Mandarin speech, as well as short melodies with pitch patterns derived from this speech. Mandarin is a tonal language in which word meaning is based in part on pitch patterning; as such we hypothesized that native speakers of Mandarin may exhibit a selective advantage for imitation that may be general (extending across all stimuli) or specific to Mandarin speech. The former hypothesis was supported, but only for imitation of “relative pitch”, that is the way in which pitch changes over time, as opposed to “absolute pitch”, which is the overall high or low quality of pitches. We also addressed musical training, which likewise had a general advantage for imitation, but in terms of absolute rather than relative pitch. These results suggest that the way you learn to use pitch through experience influences the strength and manner of associations between auditory perception and vocal production.

 

2: Imagery is necessary for optimal pitch imitation

Studies performed prior to this funding had documented a correlation between auditory imagery ability (e.g., how accurately one is able to imagine pitches from a melody) and pitch imitation accuracy (e.g., how good a singer you are). But these correlations do not show that imagery is necessary for accurate imitation. We addressed this question in an experiment in which participants were prevented from engaging in imagery. Participants first listened to and then vocally imitated short melodies. On different trials, participants were given different instructions about what to do in between these phases. In one set of trials, participants simply mentally rehearsed the melody, using auditory imagery. In another set of trials, participants quietly hummed. Previous research has shown that quiet humming interferes with auditory imagery, because imagery relies on both perception and motor regions of the brain. We found that imitation accuracy was significantly lower after people engaged in the interfering humming condition than when they underwent mental rehearsal, thus supporting the idea that imagery may be necessary for accurate imitation.

 

3: Inaccurate singers can improve, under the right conditions

The idea that singing accuracy (a form of vocal pitch imitation) is an inherited “talent” looms large in modern Western society. Furthermore, because vocal pitch imitation is not well understood, primary school chorus instructors lack tools needed to remediate children with poor pitch matching ability. The combination of these factors leads to heartbreaking outcomes in many adults, who avoid any singing due to childhood memories of being referred to as a “non-singer” and being asked to “mouth the words” by teachers while participating in group singing. Two studies tested a scientifically-driven remediation for poor singing. These studies followed from the hypothesis that poor singing reflects dysfunctional associations between auditory perceptual representations and motor planning in the brain. Correction of these associations by a visual interface, therefore, may help improve accuracy. We tested the robustness of a commercially available visual feedback training platform (Erol’s singer’s studio), which led to significant improvement after one brief training session, in contrast to training based just on auditory information. In another study we tested the hypothesis that accuracy would improve best after using a wide pitch range during training, in keeping with theories from music education, again using a visual interface. This hypothesis was supported, with strongest gains being found for participants who used a wide pitch range during training with visual feedback.
